item.title: Adults under financial pressures report higher anxiety and lower happiness
item.description: Adults under financial pressures report higher anxiety and lower happiness 22 February 2023 Adults in Great Britain who report borrowing more money or using more credit in the last month compared with a year ago were twice as likely to report low levels of happiness, compared with those who are not borrowing more money. A fifth of adults (22%) who reported borrowing more money or using more credit than usual in the last month, compared with a year ago, between 14 September 2022 and 8 January 2023 also reported low levels of happiness, compared with 11% of those who were not borrowing more. Those who were borrowing more money were also more likely than those who were not to report high levels of anxiety. More than 4 in 10 adults who were borrowing more money or using more credit reported high levels of anxiety Wellbeing measures by whether respondent was borrowing more money or using more credit in the last month compared with a year ago, Great Britain, 14 September 2022 to 8 January 2023 Embed code Embed this interactive Copy Download the data .xlsx Adults who reported being behind on their energy bills, or struggling to afford their energy or rent or mortgage payments, were also more likely to report lower levels of happiness and higher levels of anxiety. More than a fifth of adults in Great Britain (22%, equal to around 11.5 million people) reported borrowing more money or using more credit than usual in the last month, compared with a year ago, when surveyed between 25 January and 5 February 2023. This is an increase from 17% of adults surveyed the year before (between 19 and 30 January 2022). item.title: Rise in young people not in education, employment or training
item.description: Rise in young people not in education, employment or training 23 February 2023 The number of young people who are not in education, employment or training (NEET) has risen by more than 60,000 in the past three months. A total of 788,000 people aged 16 to 24 were estimated to be NEET from October to December 2022, up from 724,000 in the previous quarter a â€“ an increase of 64,000. This means that NEET young people now make up an estimated 11.5% of the UK's population of 16- to 24-year-olds. The number of male and female NEETs both rose by 32,000 in the last quarter. Of the total number of NEETs, 416,000 were men and 372,000 were women. There has also been an increase in the number of young people who were NEET and unemployed. In October to December 2022, this figure was estimated to be 299,000, an increase of 32,000 on the previous quarter. A quarter (25%) of trading businesses also expect to increase their prices in March 2023, according to our latest business insights and conditions survey. Energy prices remain the top reason trading businesses are considering doing so, with 35% citing this reason. For trading businesses in the accommodation and food service activities (hospitality) industry, 45% expect a rise in prices. We urge caution when interpreting questions on future expectations as the employees responding to the survey may not always have full oversight of the business. item.title: Students hit by rising cost of living
item.description: Students hit by rising cost of living 24 February 2023 More than 9 in 10 university students in England say their cost of living has risen over the last year, with many worried it will negatively affect their studies. Some 92% of higher education students said their cost of living had increased compared with last year, according to a survey carried out between 30 January and 13 February 2023. Around half (49%) felt they had financial difficulties, with 33% saying these were minor and 16% saying they had major money problems. The survey data suggest this may be leading to higher debt levels, with 3 in 10 students (30%) saying they had taken on new debt in response to rising living costs, up from 25% in early November 2022. Of those, 71% said this was because their student loan did not cover their living costs. More than three-quarters (78%) of students were concerned that rising prices may affect how well they do in their studies, while more than a third (35%) reported they are now less likely to do further study after finishing their course. This could be affecting studentsâ€™ mental health, with around 46% reporting their mental health and well-being had worsened since the start of the Autumn term 2022. item.title: Around 1 in 11 adults report running out of food
item.description: Around 1 in 11 adults report running out of food 27 February 2023 Adults across Britain are experiencing food insecurity and are having to cut down on portion sizes or skip meals altogether. Around 1 in 11 adults (9%) reported they had often or sometimes run out of food and could not afford to buy more in the past month. That is according to figures from our Winter Survey tracking the impact of winter pressures, which were collected from 18 to 29 January 2023. Around one in eight (13%) said they had cut down on meal sizes or skipped meals altogether in the past month because there was not enough money for food. Of those, 21% reported having done so on more than 14 days in the month. The survey also shows that nearly one in five adults (18%) waiting for NHS treatment say they had an appointment cancelled or delayed in the past month. Around 3 in 10 (31%) employed or self-employed adults who were waiting for NHS treatment said it had affected their work. Reasons their work was affected that they cited included having to change working tasks, not going for promotion or training opportunities, and finding new employment. item.title: Record growth in prices food and drink manufacturers charged in January 2023
item.description: Record growth in prices food and drink manufacturers charged in January 2023 8 March 2023 The prices UK food and drinks manufacturers charged for their products rose 17.1% in the year to January 2023, the highest annual rate on record. The prices manufacturers paid for their materials and fuels rose 19.8% in the year to January 2023. This is a slight decrease from a peak of 22.7% in the year to October 2022. This reflects rising prices of commodities worldwide, which have been affected by rising energy prices, supply chain disruption following the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Global prices of natural gas, food and fertilisers have all seen rapid increases during 2021 and 2022. The prices food and drink manufacturers charge to their customers are different to the prices consumers pay in shops and supermarkets. Consumer prices for food and non-alcoholic drinks rose 16.8% in the year to January 2023. The chart compares the increase in prices manufacturers charged for different food and drink items, and the prices retailers charged. There is a positive association between the food and drink prices charged by manufacturers and paid by consumers. Dairy products, such as milk and cheese, saw some of the largest price increases both among manufacturers and retailers. item.title: 2.5 million working days lost to strikes in late 2022
item.description: 2.5 million working days lost to strikes in late 2022 8 March 2023 An estimated 2.5 million working days were lost because of industrial disputes between June and December 2022. Of these, almost 2 million (79%) were among workers in transport, storage, information and communication. This includes both railway workers and postal workers, both of which went on strike in this period. The second highest number of days lost between June and December 2022 was in education (226,000), with 174,000 working days lost during strikes in November 2022. There is some evidence of strikes having an impact on output in the affected industries. Rail and postal workers held several strike days in December 2022; this month also saw the largest falls in output for these industries. In December 2022, rail transport output fell 7.0%, and postal and courier activities fell 10.5%. item.title: Mortgage Calculator shows rising monthly repayment costs
item.description: Mortgage Calculator shows rising monthly repayment costs 8 March 2023 The monthly cost of a new mortgage rose by 61% in the year to December 2022 for the average semi-detached house in the UK. Our new personalised Mortgage Calculator , based on our House Price Index (HPI), shows how rising interest rates have caused monthly mortgage payments to rise sharply in England, Scotland and Wales. Because mortgage loans tend to be for large amounts of money, small increases in mortgage rates can have a big impact on the amount that households will have to pay back each month. Based on a 75% loan-to-value ratio, the average mortgage rate offered by lenders on a five-year fixed rate loan was 5.05% in December 2022, according to the Bank of England . That figure was up from 1.59% in December 2021. At a 75% loan-to-value rate, the average monthly mortgage repayment on a 25-year term for a semi-detached UK property was Â£1,262 in December 2022. This was a Â£481 (61%) increase on December 2021. Other property types have also experienced similar changes between December 2021 and December 2022. The monthly mortgage repayments on an average detached UK property rose by 60.7% to Â£2,041. The repayments on an average terraced UK property increased by 59.6% to Â£1,063 per month, while flats and maisonettes experienced a 54.6% rise to Â£1,028 per month.
